results.title: Tabaluga. Volume 4
results.creator_credit: Yoram Gross, Tabaluga GbmH and Zweites Deutsches Fernsehen
results.brief_description: A German-Australian co-production created by Peter Maffay, Gregor Rottschalk and Rolf Zuckowski, Tabaluga is the last surviving dragon on earth. Using a combination of fire and flight, both peaceful options, Tabaluga fights his nemesis the evil snowman Arktos, intent on ruining Tabaluga’s home of Greenland by covering it with snow and ice, thus making it inhospitable. Popular with adults and children alike, “Tabaluga” is in its third series and a feature film is in production. “Dragons don’t cry” (story by Gregor Rottschalk): Tabaluga is surprised to discover he can cry after crashing while flying. Travelling with Happy, they come across a strange fruit that Happy eats. Arktos’ number one henchman James is also interested in the fruit and takes it back to his master. The next day, both Arktos and Happy suffer from a sleeping sickness. “The Big cloud” (story by Gregor Rottschalk, Heike Lage): Snowballs packed with a secret formula that turns them into thick, black clouds are assailing Greenland. Counteracting the power will require activating the molten lava in the volcano through the assistance of an army of special ants. “The Visitors who came in from the cold” (story by Gregor Rottschalk): Productivity is down at Arktos’ sardine factory and there is a mass walkout by penguin staff, including their brethren working throughout the rest of Ice World. En masse, the penguins head for the sunny climes of Greenland. Voices provided by Keith Scott, Robyn Moore, Jamie Oxenbould.

results.title: Symbol boy
results.creator_credit: Bruce Moir, Tom Daly, Film Australia and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A teaching aid made for the film Mr Symbol man. The film animates a system of pictographs created by Charles K. Bliss to help nonverbal people communicate. The film shows how the symbols work by using them to illustrate one day in the life of a mute child. Animation by Les Drew.

results.title: Sylvie's story
results.creator_credit: Tina Horne, Gerry Rogers, Kathleen Shannon and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Sylvie’s Story is part of the series The Next Step, which examines the services needed by and available to battered women. The film recreates the experience of Sylvie, a battered woman who seeks shelter in a Montreal transition house. Faced with the threat of violence, loneliness, the lack of financial resources or information about services, the victim is often understandably reluctant to seek help. The film emphasizes the importance for women of speaking out and sharing their experiences with other women. The film also points out the role of the transition house in putting the battered woman in touch with appropriate legal and social services.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tina Horne, Gerry Rogers, Kathleen Shannon and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Sydney city life: 1899-1948
results.creator_credit: National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: Explores the changes to inner city life in Sydney through five decades in a black and white production with a musical backdrop and without narration. Chronicles the story of ever-changing fashions, transport, architecture and everyday life and work.

results.title: Sydney at war: the untold story
results.creator_credit: Claude Gonzalez, Tamara Popper, Australian Film Commission, Bavarian Film Studios and New South Wales Film and Television Office
results.brief_description: Intriguing documentary about a midget submarine attack on Sydney Harbour by the Japanese during World War II. On the evening of 1st June 1942, a surprise offensive left twenty-one allied and six Japanese dead. Survivors, witnesses and relatives, from both Australia and Japan, recount their memories of the event and how it still affects their lives today. A moving portrait of a singular incident that brought the realisation that the war was not an event happening overseas - how prepared was Australia for invasion? Using a mixture of archival, contemporary footage and interviews (and with a moving musical score composed by Sam Petty) this poignant documentary recalls in a personal way the lives and losses of those caught up in the perils of war. Written, directed and co-produced by Claude Gonzalez.

results.title: Swing (Gatlif)
results.creator_credit: Tony Gatlif, Laurent Dusothoit, Nathalie Duran and Princes Films
results.brief_description: Gatlif’s passion for Gypsies and their music continues as a theme in this his fourth feature film. A young French boy Max discovers Gypsy music and lifestyle whilst on summer holidays with his grandmother. He takes guitar lessons from a master player of Manouche Jazz in return for reading and writing letters to Social Security on his teacher’s behalf. During lessons he begins to fain headaches to spend more time with the beautiful gypsy tomboy ‘Swing’. Swing teaches Max, who is from the wealthy side of the river, about nature and brings him to some wild musical evenings at the caravans.

results.title: T-Minus 4 years, 9 months, 30 days
results.creator_credit: Ben Hill, Joel Banow, Robert Vitarelli, Arthur Kane, David Buksbaum, William Crawford and CBS News
results.brief_description: Interviewer Walter Cronkite speaks to John Glenn about Saturn booster rockets and Dr Von Braun on the fuel and engines in the rockets. John Glenn, using a scale model, shows how astronauts will make observations on the moon, return from its surface in the Lunar Module and rendezvous with the Command Module before returning to earth.

results.title: System 6: a fragile nest
results.creator_credit: Jeni Kendell, Craig Collie, Michael Daley, ABC-TV (Australia), CSIRO and Environmental Protection Authority, W A
results.brief_description: System 6 is the name given by the Environmental Protection Agency to the area around Perth. It includes the Darling Ranges and the Swan River System. The detrimental effect of the urban sprawl and industrialisation in the karri forests, on sand dunes, and under the sea, is examined. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jeni Kendell, Craig Collie, Michael Daley, ABC-TV (Australia), CSIRO and Environmental Protection Authority, W A

results.title: Symbolism in literature
results.creator_credit: Herman Epstein, Herb Schick, Noel Korn and Sigma Education Films
results.brief_description: The basic theories of symbolism are discussed as an introduction. Edgar Allen Poe’s chilling story, “The Tell Tale Heart”, helps us to uncover symbols and their meanings, enhancing our enjoyment and understanding of fiction. Also briefly discusses symbolism in Van Gogh’s work. Uses animation to accompany Poe’s story.

results.title: Sykes
results.brief_description: Sykes Williams is a blind, semi-retired musician, a great favourite in the small bar where he plays piano to supplement his social security benefits. He is seen on his daily excursions into his neighbourhood, and at the bar, as he eloquently expresses his opinions on a wide range of concerns. A portrait of an involved, vital human being as well as an exploration of the problems of the blind and ageing.
